column3: Repair of canalicular laceration with a pigtail probe HD
column4:
A pigtail probe can be used to repair a canalicular laceration.  The advantage of the pigtail probe is that you do not need to retrieve the stents from the nose, and the procedure can be done more easily under local anesthesia.  However, sometimes it can be difficult to pass the pigtail probe in the area of the common canaliculus, which can result in canalicular damage.  I personally prefer Crawford stents (bicanalicular with retrieval from the nose) for repair of canalicular lacerations, but I think it is important to feel comfortable using the pigtail probe, because it may be necessary in some scenarios.  Monocanalicular stents can be used as well in some situations.  

For a written transcript of this video, please see http://webeye.ophth.uiowa.edu/eyeforum/video/plastics/6/9-pigtail-probe.htm

column3: SCAR MANAGEMENT - Dr. Karthik Ram - Tamil
column4:
Scar management refers to the various techniques and approaches used to minimize the appearance and improve the functionality of scars. Scars are a natural part of the healing process after an injury, surgery, or other trauma to the skin. While it is not possible to completely eliminate scars, certain methods can help reduce their visibility and make them less noticeable. Here are some common scar management techniques:

Wound care: Proper wound care during the initial healing phase is crucial for minimizing scar formation. Keeping the wound clean, moist, and protected can promote optimal healing and reduce the risk of complications.

Silicone gel sheets or creams: Silicone-based products, such as gel sheets or creams, are often used to manage scars. They create a protective barrier over the scar, hydrate the skin, and help regulate collagen production, which can improve the appearance of scars over time.

Steroid injections: For hypertrophic or keloid scars, corticosteroid injections may be recommended. These injections help reduce inflammation, flatten the scar, and minimize itching or discomfort associated with these types of scars.

Surgical revision: In some cases, surgical scar revision may be considered. This involves removing the old scar and creating a new, less noticeable scar. Surgical revision is typically used for large, raised, or cosmetically significant scars.

column3: Keratoconus Surgery: Femto LASER Assisted Ferrara Corneal Ring Segment Implantion
column4:
We present the surgical technique for Advanced Keratoconus using an intrastromal corneal ring segment (ICRS)

A young male presented with decreased visual acuity in his left due to irregular astigmatism caused by advanced keratoconus.
Pentacam analysis confirmed the diagnosis indicating a "croissant" phenotype of keratoconus with irregular astigmatism, increased vertical coma and inferotemporal stromal thinning (Belin ABCD grades 2-3)

A Ferrara corneal ring with 150o arc length and 200 micron of thickness was implanted. The main incision was placed in the steep corneal axis, and the stromal tunnnel was created by using the Ziemer LDV Z8 Femtosecond LASER.

An immediate 1st postoperative day improvement in uncorrected VA was verified, confirming the safety and effectiveness of modern LASER assisted ICRS Surgery for keratoconus

column3: Limbal Dermoid of a 5 Year Old Child
column4:
The five-year-old child presented with a limbal dermoid. Ablation of the dermoid was performed, and the defect was lined with Amion. The conjunctiva was sutured, leaving a delicate corneal opacity that eventually dissolved. 
Limbal dermoids are benign tumors that can cause astigmatism and affect visual acuity. Surgical removal of the dermoid is recommended to prevent visual impairment and discomfort. Ablation of the dermoid flat and lining the defect with AM is a safe and effective method of treatment. AM has been shown to have anti-inflammatory, anti-scarring, and wound-healing properties, making it an ideal material for ocular surface reconstruction.

Barry McCann was born in 1962 in Armidale NSW Australia, where he now lives with his wife Lucy, also a full time artist. Together they run McCann Fine Art, producing, selling and teaching art.He is the recipient of numerous awards and prizes and his works hang in collections around the world.

Barry McCann＊s interest in art began with his love of drawing as a young student presenting school assignments with more illustrations than text and developed further as a young adult during his college years. Drawing became a way of gaining some pocket money and new friends.

His artistic interest and flair became very advantageous with his chosen trade as a Chef and Cake Decorator, but it wasn＊t until he enrolled in an introductory Watercolour course at the Canberra School of Arts, A.C.T. that his appetite for art really began. Armed with an insatiable thirst for art knowledge, he stumbled upon a book about the life and works of artist John Singer Sargent and this has influenced his work and artistic vision ever since. He has studied with many leading artists in their field in order to build on his skills and in 2000 he began painting as a fulltime career. Barry＊s love of art has taken him to some of the best museums and art galleries in the world where he draws constant inspiration.

His subject matter usually involves an animated object with a dramatic light effect and enjoys the constant challenge of trying to portray the illusion of both movement and form with a narrative theme. The pursuit of conveying beauty in his work is paramount. He believes that art is a visual language and should need little explanation＃ you should just like looking at it. Finding the middle ground where traditional representational art can be fused with a more modern look is something he strives for. His work usually portrays a traditional scene and is painted using loose edges, obvious brushstrokes, dribbles, spatter or ※movement lines§ all of which are used in contemporary art practices.

Barry McCann would like his viewers to not have an opinion of his work, but a connection or a response..

column3: Exploring the Suprachoroidal Space
column4:
Rhett Buckler ''Best in Show'' Award ASRS 2014 Film Festival
Video by Flavio Rezende, MD, PhD and Renaud Duval, MD

Suprachoroidal space surgery is an emerging area of interest for vitreoretinal surgeons.  From drainage of suprachoroidal hemorrhage or choroidal effusions to suprachoroidal buckling, this new field is showing great promise.  Yet, without direct visualization of the suprachoroidal space, safe navigation with our instruments is a matter of concern to many.  In a series of patients undergoing suprachoroidal space surgery, 20G and 23G endoscopes were used to visualize the suprachoroidal space in vivo and explore the anatomical relationships of structures such as the vortex veins and the ciliary nerves.

column3: Exploring the Suprachoroidal Space
column4:
Rhett Buckler ''Best in Show'' Award ASRS 2014 Film Festival
Video by Flavio Rezende, MD, PhD and Renaud Duval, MD

Suprachoroidal space surgery is an emerging area of interest for vitreoretinal surgeons.  From drainage of suprachoroidal hemorrhage or choroidal effusions to suprachoroidal buckling, this new field is showing great promise.  Yet, without direct visualization of the suprachoroidal space, safe navigation with our instruments is a matter of concern to many.  In a series of patients undergoing suprachoroidal space surgery, 20G and 23G endoscopes were used to visualize the suprachoroidal space in vivo and explore the anatomical relationships of structures such as the vortex veins and the ciliary nerves.

column4:

The yield of a conventional ''dry'' vitreous biopsy is approximately 1cc of undiluted vitreous, which is often insufficient for the battery of tests required.  Inspired by the crow's ingenuity in Aesop's ''The Crow and the Pitcher'', we demonstrate a safe and efficient way to obtain a large volume of undiluted vitreous by using manual Perfluoron infusion.

column3: Lower Canalicular Laceration Repair
column4:
The lower lid trauma frequently involves lower canaliculus as well. If a proper repair is done tear drainage is not impaired and if it is not done properly it not only leads to unsightly appearance but also incessant tearing from the involved eye as mainly the lower canaliculus helps in drainage of tears from eye to the nose.
This video shows a young man, with a 3 days old laceration of left lower lid involving lower canaliculus. This video can also be seen at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PK4emmL3hq0 . The lower canaliculus was repaired and a nylon thread was passed through the upper and lower punctii using a curved instrument called pig tail and the suture was left in place for 4 weeks. After removal of the suture the canaliculus remained patent and no tearing was seen in the involved eye. The video is being shown to give some tips to junior ophthalmologists to learn how to repair a lacerated canaliculus.

column3: A Tribute to Late Dr. Victor C. Rambo -Community outreach programme
column4: Dr. Victor C. Rambo was moved by the plight of many, who didn't have access to good hospitals where eye surgery could be performed. He worked out a method to reach these people and help them through a well equipped mobile eye hospital. He used to go to the remote areas with his team and stay there for 2 to 3 weeks. Conduct OPDs, do refractions, dispense spectacles, fit readymade prosthetic eyes, dispense eye drops and operate on patients for various eye diseases using contemporary surgical techniques in a sterile environment in a scientific way. He would stay in these make shift eye hospital for a week after surgery to look after the operated patient. The results were amazing, comparable to the results of surgical procedures done in any reputed hospital set up. He was a dedicated worker who believed in wiping out blindness from the face of this earth.  CMC continued to serve the community on similar principles for many decades. Now we do surgery only at our medical college or a district hospital. Through Mobile Eye Hospital we have been able to reach hundreds of thousands, many of whom would never have been rehabilitated without this intervention. The video shows the organization of the services, the clips of OPDs, refraction stations, dispensing of medicines, clips of surgical procedures, post operative dressing sessions and community kitchen. God bless that compassionate soul who conceived this great idea "to reach the unreached" and practiced it for many decades, serving the creation of Almighty God.

column3: Friends of Vision Foundation
column4: In 2005 while working in Northern Namibia as a volunteer eye surgeon, Dr. Colvard became aware of the desperate situation faced by many children at a school not far from the hospital where he was working. At the request of a local school administrator, he visited the school in Oshakati and discovered an isolated, poorly funded school where a heroic group of teachers were struggling to provide an education for approximately 1000 poor and vulnerable children. At the school there were no books, paper or pencils, the classrooms were dilapidated and a large number of students, many of whom were orphaned, where arriving at school every day malnourished and hungry.

column3: Pup's Quest In Africa
column4:
The single greatest challenge for the children at Oshakati School and, indeed for the children of all underdeveloped nations in Africa, is providing effective reading education. Reading is the foundation of all learning, and yet when we arrived at Oshakati School the majority of the children were functionally illiterate. 
The future of an African child who cannot read is grim beyond imagination. An illiterate child in Africa faces a life of backbreaking labor subsistence farmng  and abject poverty In the emerging economies of Africa, however, simple basic competency in reading virtually guarantees an escape from poverty. 
Our challenge was to create a low cost  educational program for Oshakati School that would foster higher levels of literacy. 
In poorer neighborhoods of urban centers and rural areas throughout Africa there are two major obstacles to providing children with a sound education in reading. 
The first is that the majority of teachers in impoverished schools, not only have little training in reading education, they often are not fluent in English themselves. This is true even in countries where English is the national language.   
The second problem is that most children from poorer neighborhoods enter school speaking only their tribal dialect.
To address these challenges, we started a small educational software company dedicated to the mission of creating a comprehensive, tablet computer - based, interactive program that allows African teachers with little training and low levels of fluency in English to teach reading to students for whom English is a second language 
The program we created , called Pup＊s Quest , that uses animation, voice and handwriting recognition software, songs and captivating stories to teach children to read, write and spell English in a way that is engaging, highly effective for English language learners.

column3: Safran modified McAhmed suture: Repair of iris/pupil defect
column4: This is an pupil repair using a modified "McAhmed"  suturing technique. I find this method to be faster and easier than a sliding slipknot with the advantage that you can do many passes and ties with a single prolene suture.  I've used the same technique to tie a cerclage and find it very controlled. It is a modification of Ike Ahmed's "McAhmed" technique which itself a modified McCannel.  Thanks to both Ike and Dr. McCannel for their contributions!

column3: Crystalens Z syndrome repair with CTR/sutured CTS segment by Steven G. Safran MD
column4: This is a patient referred in with a Z syndrome who has a significantly fibrosed capsular bag.  The bag is re opened and the dislocated Crystalens removed. A CTR is placed with some difficulty and then a sutured CTS segment is placed in the area of zonular weakness on the temporal side to stabilize the capsular bag and the new intraocular lens.

column3: Slit lamp LRI by Steven G. Safran MD
column4: This is an LRI done at the slit lamp for post operative astigmatism of 1.25-1.5 diopters refractive astigmatism in the OD.  A fixed 600u diamond blade is used.  The nasal cut is done with the right hand and the temporal cut with the left hand.

column3: Nightmare pterygium: removal with MMC and conj. graft/ fibrin glue by Steven G. Safran MD
column4: This is a patient having his fourth surgery for this recurrent pterygium.  (my first crack at it).  I put him on autologous serum based tears for a month to prepare his ocular surface and then did this procedure with aggressive mitomycin C and steroids and continued use of serum based tears.  He has not recurred now 3 months later at all and the cornea is quite clear with very good visual acuity.....20/30 uncorrected with just trace cornea haze that is improving.  Prior to surgery he could only see by turning his head to the side as the pterygium completely covered his pupil.

column3: Conjunctivochalasis treatment with Ellman radiofrequency surgery by Steven G. Safran MD
column4: This patient has marked conjunctivochalasis causing tearing and foreign body sensation that is treated using the Ellman Surgitron Dual RF 120 Generator under topical anesthesia in an office setting. Slit lamp video taken immediately before and after treatment demonstrates the reduction of the excess tissue and improved adherence of conjunctiva to the eye with lid movement.

column3: Conjunctivalchalasis repair: amniotic membrane graft with fibrin glue by Steven G. Safran MD
column4: This is a patient with conjunctivalchalasis due to poorly adherent redundant conjunciva.  This is surgically managed with resection of the excess conj. and replacement with amniotic membrane which is glued in place with fibrin glue.  The procedure is done with topical anesthesia.  The amniotic membrane is usually overgrown by new conjunctiva that is tight and adherent to the globe without redundancy.

column3: iris capture repair with pupil reconstruction by Steven G. Safran MD
column4: This is a patient referred to me for chronic iris capture.  She has glare from the dilated pupil and the exposed edge of the implant. The iris is adherent to the posterior capsule for about 270 degrees.  After dissecting the iris off the posterior capsule and pulling some adhesions out of the angle I reconstructed the pupil with 10-0 proline on slip knot sutures.
